title: Black Box Variational Inference with a Deterministic Objective: Faster, More Accurate, and Even More Black Box

last_post.content:
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05527
'Black Box Variational Inference with a Deterministic Objective: Faster, More Accurate, and Even More Black Box'
- Ryan Giordano, Martin Ingram, Tamara Broderick

The de facto approach to fitting general-purpose variational approximations to posterior distributions has been to either use closed-form updates (as in e.g. MFVI) or stochastic gradient methods (as in e.g. BBVI, ADVI). This work recalls an alternative to stochastic gradient methods, the sample average approximation (SAA), and demonstrates that as applied to fitting certain variational families, it can offer certain appealing advantages.

#sparxivdigest

title: Conditional Adapters: Parameter-efficient Transfer Learning with Fast Inference

last_post.content:
RT @taolei15949106
Introducing Conditional Adapters (CoDA) from Google Research!
Adaptation methods (e.g. Adapter and LoRA) can finetune LMs with minimal parameter updates, but their inference remains expensive. CoDA makes LMs faster to use, and works for three modalities!

ChatGPT playing Zork etc.:

"Our experiments show that ChatGPT performs competitively compared to all the existing systems but still exhibits a low level of intelligence. Precisely, ChatGPT can not construct the world model by playing the game or even reading the game manual; it may fail to leverage the world knowledge that it already has; it cannot infer the goal of each step as the game progresses."

Checkout our newest work: Self-Refine: Iterative Refinement with Self-Feedback

We show that LLMs such as GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 can:
1. Generate a draft output
2. Generate textual feedback critiquing it
3. Refine the draft output using the feedback
4. Iterate, as needed

Improves performance on 7 tasks including code and creative text generation. No supervised training, no RL, no human feedback!

Led by Aman Madaan
PDF: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.17651.pdf
Project page: https://selfrefine.info

My second thought—and don't confuse this for an endorsement of the paper—was much darker: we probably DO need work on this, and on how humans are influenced by it. The latter is the primary of the subject of the paper.

On the large AI models, this preprint synthesises what we know so far https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15259

In short: it is mathematically impossible to have AIs combining the following properties:

1) High number of parameters
2) Robustness to poisoning (e.g. fake data)
3) Privacy-preserving

title: Better Language Models of Code through Self-Improvement

last_post.content:
I'm looking at this and wondering if this is at the right level of abstraction to think about. It seems too low level.
---
RT @johnjnay
Simple Self-Improvement of Code LLMs

1) Pre-train & Fine-tune code LLM, gaining knowledge
2) LLM then generates pseudo outputs
3) Add that to original data & train for next epoch

Significantly improves code summarization & code generation performance

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01228

title: Validated Names for Experimental Studies on Race and Ethnicity

last_post.content:
In many studies, we use names (like vignettes, or applications).
Names bring a lot of baggage with them.

For example, with ‘Hazel’, you already are forming ideas about age, sex, likely SES etc.

Same with Arthur Worthington III,
or Ozamataz Buckshank.

No name is neutral.

In this study, 4,026 people rated 600 names on numerous attributes.

Full data is available here https://osf.io/ahpvq/

Now you can ‘match’ names on all sorts of characteristics

From @cdcrabtree

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-023-01947-0

9/

ahhh this new #bayesian ordered beta regression model family (package: https://github.com/saudiwin/ordbetareg_pack; paper: https://doi.org/10.1017/pan.2022.20) is so so neat! I have an outcome bounded at 1 and 32, and the model successfully predicts discrete 1s and 32s, as well as a continuous range in between! #rstats #brms #statsodon

Essentially, we need to adopt methods from #CognitiveScience & #HCI into #AI/#ML practice.

My colleagues & I at #PARC have one example at #ACMTiiS.
https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3366501

The work:
1. Begins by studying how experts coach people.
2. Uses AI algorithms to embody those principles.
3. Puts #AI in an interface.
4. Evaluates long-term impact in real people's lives as they live it through an empirical, observational study.

This is hard work - it took 3 years to complete! (2/n)

"The very terms used by the researchers who named these benchmark assessments—“general language understanding,” “natural language inference,” “reading comprehension,” “commonsense reasoning,” and so on—reveal an assumption that humanlike understanding is required to perform well on these tasks. But do these tasks actually require such understanding? Not necessarily." - @melaniemitchell, https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.13966.pdf

title: Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback

last_post.content:
"As AI systems become more capable, we would like to enlist their help to supervise other AIs. We experiment with methods for training a harmless AI assistant through self-improvement, without any human labels identifying harmful outputs. The only human oversight is provided through a list of rules or principles, and so we refer to the method as 'Constitutional AI'."

[2212.08073] Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback
https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08073#

#aitraining #aiethics #ai

Knitted origami
Elizabeth L. Wilmer

"Techniques are presented for embedding horizontal, vertical, and45◦diagonal crease lines into garter stitch knitted fabric. While theseare mostly based on standard lace knitting stitches, the horizon-tal creases use double-cable-crossed elongated stitches in a non-standard way. This crease library suffices to knit a model of a squaretwist, a foundational origami tessellation unit."
